Those experiencing grief and loss are also in need. You present a false choice (between helping those who are homeless and helping those who are suicidal). Most Crisis Lines all over the country handle calls from the suicidal, the starving, and the homeless- because a person experiencing any of these things is in need of emotional support.

I agree that we cannot prevent every suicide- as fatal self-injury is a choice for each individual. Research suggests that prevention works- and intervention can work really well at the site. The Golden Gate Bridge is still open- and still beautiful- and there have been specific steps taken to make it more difficult to complete a suicide at that location.

It would be nice if this memorial had those beams of light shining up from the bottom. I think it would feel more positive, that way.

To me, this memorial looks like a couple of big storm drains. Cold, dark, wet, endless, empty.

I'd probably think about it if I went there, so I don't intend to go any time soon. I much preferred the beams of light that shot up into the sky soon after and on the anniversary of the attacks, than these deep, dark wells of teary, watery grief. Nice planning, people.

People walking by will not be sucked in by a vortex of grief- that is silly, you're right. It is quite likely that someone will plan to go there to enact their suicide as an outlet for already overwhelming grief. See Golden Gate Bridge and suicides. It makes sense to put up crisis-line call boxes as research supports they can work to lower suicide deaths at areas of cultural significance. Plus they are cheap and easy on the eye.

The other big thing preventing suicides there is that the jump just doesn't look deadly. It looks like it would produce significant pain and crippling injury- and not certain death. Science knows that the last thing a suicidal person wants is more pain.

Many of the comments here seem callous and sarcastic. Since when is sarcasm appropriate in a discussion of suicide? Never. Of course people in terrible grief and depression sometimes attempt suicide, and they sometimes succeed.  It is absolutely appropriate to talk about this or any other public health concern. Now is the time to decide that this issue  be seriously addressed in the design phase of any new public structure before building begins.

No, the primary reason the SAT is criticized is that whites outscore blacks by about 1 standard deviation and Hispanics by a slightly smaller amount, and high-income students outscore low-income students. These score differences are an obstacle to people who want all races and income groups to be equally distributed at colleges, including the selective ones, so they try to delegitimize standardized tests.

I scored nearly perfect scores on my SATs long ago, and reading this article made me think that the Posse program is one of the smartest innovations in tertiary education in a long time. As a culture, the U.S. needs to wake up to the ways in which we fail to tap all students' full potential to learn, to self-actualize, to contribute, and to succeed. The sink-or-swim, hyper-individualist philosophy undergirding SAT achievement is a philosophy of the early twentieth century. About time we shed it.
I'd be willing to bet that the great majority of posters knocking the SATs did poorly on them. Just look at what happened to CUNY when standards were abandoned. There is no free lunch in education.

If it was so cut & dry, it wouldn't be such an important issue. Hundreds of homes in my area were forclosed upon when homeowners tried to get a modification. The banks told them either to stop making their current payment or to send a conditional modified payment. When the modification request was denied-and they were always denied, the borrowerers resumed payments, sometimes for several more months and were served with forclosure notices. The banks not only refused to accept additional payments, they were told the resumed payments had not been applied to their outstanding mortgage payments.

It was a scam through and through!

While all those things you wrote may be true, the experiences of these "Posse" students highlight the SAT's inadequacy as a accurate measurement of anything useful to a school. Based solely on the article, I would say the Posse Foundation takes the "whole person" concept into account, which, while more labor-intensive and subjective, when applied correctly can give amazing results.

There are probably many other great ideas out there for leveling the playing field for America's students. Making college more accessible and affordable is necessary, but providing true equal opportunity is really where fundamental change occurs.

I am attending a small private college that eliminated SAT scores in its admissions program. The quality of the students I meet doesn't seem to have suffered because of it.

The SAT is not a perfect test. It's not even a great test. It is, however, quite accurate as a *general* measure of where an applicant stands, at that particular moment, relative to his or her peers in terms of essential reading, math, and writing skills. (The College Board officially no longer considers it an aptitude test). Many students who earn A grades in AP-level English classes still lack some very basic comprehension and composition skills -- it doesn't mean they're not capable of acquiring those skills, just that their grades don't tell the whole story.

The SAT and the ACT are the only measures that colleges can use to directly compare applicants: assuming that someone has in fact taken his or her own test, it can't be inflated, fudged, or pumped up with extra credit, no matter how much money someone has spent on prep. Of course scores directly correlate with family income. Admissions officers know this and view applications accordingly, at least when it comes to poor (minority) applicants who clearly have potential.

To the people who complain that these tests don't reflect creativity or social acumen or any other of a dozen warm and fuzzy measures, consider that American schools are unique in considering warm and fuzzy measures at all. In most countries, test scores are *all* that count. In the US, weak scores will hurt, but if an applicant is truly stellar otherwise, some excellent colleges will look past them.

Hi Pam,

I wonder why you think that Posse Scholars are from suburban schools. They aren't -- it's a program for inner-city students.

And you're right that the schools that work with Posse do so because they feel they benefit from the relationship. Small liberal arts colleges in rural areas are largely white, so Posse is a way to "import" diversity, as you put it. But there's more to it than that. Jenny Rickard, Bryn Mawr's Chief Enrollment Officer, said that in large part because of their experience with Posse, Bryn Mawr has changed its admissions criteria to depend less on the SAT. "I wish we could scale the Posse selection process," she said.

Some Posse partner schools are also trying to bring a Posse-style small group to other students. DePauw, which puts every first year student in a small group, has taken it the furthest. But others schools, too, have learned from Posse about how a tight social network can help students succeed.

Tina Rosenberg
Author of Fixes

It's a mistake to equate the local racial make-up of Posse partner colleges' communities with a lack of racial diversity in their student bodies: these are schools with national reputations and national draw, the vast majority of whose students don't come from the surrounding area.

The rural location and community demographics of most elite liberal arts colleges, however, can provide an additional challenge to urban and/or non-white students, as these are yet more ways that their new surroundings feel alien to them.

The key piece of wisdom to draw from both the Posse program and work like Towson's is that it's not enough to simply admit a kid to college, drop him or her on the steps to the library, and sit back and wait for success. There's a tremendous amount of cultural capital involved in "doing" college well, and all efforts to provide students with this know-how, so that they have a greater chance of achieving, should be applauded and studied.

Tina, here is a link to article in a local paper about the Posse scholars from the Montgomery County Public School system in Maryland, one of the highest performing public school systems in the country. These students will be listed as part of a "Washington DC" Posse.

http://www.gazette.net/article/20120118/NEWS/701189885/1144/montgomery-c...

According to the article: "This is the second consecutive year in which the school system has had 15 Posse Foundation scholarship winners."

I'm glad that the Posse program has helped so many students. I'm also glad that they look for alternative skill sets beyond the usual pairing of GPA and SAT scores. However, two things bother me:

The Posse students are being held up as being from certain cities, when they are truly from the high performing suburban public school systems near those cities. This is not only false advertising, but hurts the students who actually attend those city schools since they appear to be being given an advantage, which they are not given.

Also, most of the Posse schools seem to be located in primarily rural areas where there is not much diversity. Posse is one way that they "import" diversity in their student body. Isn't it helping the school as much as (if not more than) the students?

There are other schools that have closed, or are closing the graduation rate gap between students of different ethnicities. None of these are Posse schools, and most of them are public schools. See this article for more:

http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/12/11/AR201012...

For example: "In 10 years, according to school data, Towson has raised black graduation rates by 30 points and closed a 14-point gap between blacks and whites. University leaders credit a few simple strategies: admitting students with good grades from strong public high schools, then tracking each student's progress with a network of mentors, counselors and welcome-to-college classes."

Actually MERS is not irrelevant to the foreclosure crisis. MERS was developed in order to sidestep a requirement to register home sales through properly established channels. That makes it easier for people to hide and fudge information. Why not just register mortgages with the county clerk? Then the information would be accessible to oversight.

If a borrower falls behind on a home that has no proper documentation then there is no real way to establish who is responsible for what. If a delinquent borrower falls behind on a home who's title has no clear owner, then against what creditor have they fallen behind? If the company demanding payment can't produce the right documentation then what claim are they laying? MERS matters. And it is a contributor. It may not be the main culprit. But MERS is certainly not without its contribution to this mess.

Here's something REALLY wild - "No person shall be ... deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law."

I've done some research and can't find a single case that holds "Unless such deprivation is at the instance of a bank."
Now here is a man who knows what they are talking about.

The entire point of the non-judicial foreclosure statutes was to ensure that no homeowner was ever foreclosed on by someone who lacked the right to foreclose. All of the noise about being in default shows great ignorance of California law. ONLY people in default were intended to be protected.

The first document that must be recorded, a Notice of Default, requires the homeowner be given 3 months to cure the default. It must also tell the homeowner details about the default including identifying who they should contact to discuss avoiding foreclosure. This isn't rocket science, it's an abject failure of the financial services industry to adhere to longstanding protocols including crazy things like - assigning notes and deeds at the time they are actually sold. Procrastinating to save pennies has turned California's non-judicial foreclosure process into a sham.
Sing Sing is closer and more fitting.
